Question: Over 5000 exoplanets have been detected so far using different techniques, most commonly used ones being Transiting and Radial Velocity (RV) method. There are several very large transiting planet and RV planet surveys, which allowed to estimate the exoplanets occurrence rate (EOR). The EOR is calculated as the fraction of stars around which an exoplanet orbits, or the number of exoplanets orbiting per star. These two EORs are different. Why in the transiting surveys usually the number of planets per star is calculated as EOR and not the fraction of stars with planets?

Options:
(A) It is impossible to directly reconstruct the distribution of planetary inclinations from Transit surveys.
(B) Transiting surveys are sensitive only to close-in (short-period) planets. Long-period planets are very hard to detect via Transiting method.
(C) Transiting method allows to determine the radius of planets only if the radius of the host star is known.
(D) In Transiting surveys, the number of planet host stars is significantly smaller than the number of planet hosting stars.

ground_truth:
It is impossible to directly reconstruct the distribution of planetary inclinations from Transit surveys.

"For transit surveys, the fraction of stars with planets is more difficult to determine because of multiplicity issues. Should misaligned, nontransiting planets be assigned evenly among all stars or into high-order multi-planet systems?" See pre-last paragraph of Sect. 3 (first columns, page 5) of https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/38/pdf

See also the first paragraph of https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/1538-4357/aac6d5/pdf


"It is impossible to reconstruct the distribution of planetary inclinations from Transit surveys" is the correct answer. In order for a planet to be detected via a transiting method, it should pass in front of the host star i.e. its orbital plane should be aligned with the line-of-sight. This means that the inclination of the planet, by definition, should be around 90 degrees. In order to calculate the fraction of stars with planets, for each star in the survey one has to compute the probability that it hosts a planet. Such calculations require knowledge of the distribution of the inclinations and orbital periods of planets. While the distribution of orbital periods can be constructed from the orbital period distribution of the transiting planets, it is not possible to reconstruct the one of the inclinations, as all the transiting planets should have an inclination close to 90 degrees.

"Transiting surveys are sensitive only to close-in (short-period) planets. Long-period planets are very hard to detect via Transiting method". This statement is absolutely correct and makes (generally) difficult to determine planet occurrence rate independent of the methods. In other words, if Transiting method was more sensitive to long-period planets, still the determination of fraction of stars hosting planets would be extremely hard when compared to the computation of number of planets per star. As explained, this is because fraction of stars with planets calculation requires knowledge of the distribution of inclinations of planets. 

"Transiting method allows to determine the radius of planets only if the radius of the host star is known" statement is absolutely correct. With the transiting method one can determine the planet-to-star radius ratio. However, independent of this, the determination of fraction of stars hosting planets would be extremely hard when compared to the computation of number of planets per star. As explained, this is because fraction of stars with planets calculation requires knowledge of the distribution of inclinations of planets.

"In Transit surveys the number of planet host stars is significantly smaller than the number of planet hosting stars". This statement is absolutely correct, which means a lot of stars have to be surveyed to detect a reasonable number of transiting planets to compute the occurrence rate of planets. However, this fact does not lead to preference to any of the two options to calculate the planet occurrence rate. As explained, the main challenge to compute the fraction of stars with transiting planets is to obtain the distribution of inclinations of planets.
